docs.abstract: Don’t colors only exist in our head, man?
docs.snippet: Don’t colors only exist in our head, man?
docs.lead_paragraph: Brett writes: I perceive many colors in the blue-green spectrum as gray. My wife corrects me in public when I call a color by the “wrong” name. But I believe that our senses are notoriously unreliable — who can say whose colors are “right” and whose are “wrong?”

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Correcting the Color Blind
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: With the publication of two new books, Gerald Murnane might finally find an American audience.
docs.snippet: With the publication of two new books, Gerald Murnane might finally find an American audience.
docs.lead_paragraph: Goroke, Victoria, a former stagecoach stop in southeastern Australia, pop. 200, is not the sort of place you would expect to host a daylong academic symposium. About five hours from Melbourne by car, the town has the feel of an evacuation nearly complete. Empty storefronts line the main street; the local pub closed two years ago. Drive a few minutes outside Goroke, and the only signs of life arrive at dusk, when the kangaroos emerge from the brush to stare down passers-by from the edge of the road. But last December, about 40 scholars, critics, editors and general readers made the journey for a series of lectures on the work of Gerald Murnane. The author, who has lived in Goroke for the last decade, prefers not to travel, and he had suggested the scholars convene at the local golf club, where he plays a weekly game and also regularly tends bar.

headline.main: Is the Next Nobel Laureate in Literature Tending Bar in a Dusty Australian Town?

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Stream System: The Collected Short Fiction of Gerald Murnane (Book)

docs.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on withholding information from a family member that may be painful to hear and handling unfairness at work.
docs.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on withholding information from a family member that may be painful to hear and handling unfairness at work.
docs.lead_paragraph: When my beloved 92-year-old mother became gravely ill and passed away last May, a first cousin who lives close by requested that I not tell her 92-year-old mother (my mother’s ex-sister-in-law) about the illness (and death) should I see her in the park. She felt that it would be too difficult for her mother to accept and might cause mental and physical problems. During the summer, when I did cross paths with my aunt, she asked me how my mother was. Hesitating, I said that everything was just fine. Afterward, I felt bad and angry that I had lied to my aunt; I felt she should have been told. My aunt wasn’t even able to say goodbye to my mother during her illness or to attend the funeral and memorial services. I promised myself that should I see my aunt again, I would inform her in a very compassionate way about my mom’s passing.

headline.main: Was It O.K. to Let an Aging Relative Believe My Mother Was Still Alive?
headline.print_headline: Was It O.K. to Let an Aging Relative Believe My Mother Was Still Alive?

docs.abstract: Are they good for the environment? Or are they just sheds?
docs.snippet: Are they good for the environment? Or are they just sheds?
docs.lead_paragraph: Taylor writes: My girlfriend and I live off-grid in a tiny house that I built. I do this because I have a libertarian streak and value self-sufficiency above all. She believes that our lifestyle is actually creating a positive environmental impact. I do feel good about that part of it, but I don’t believe that we actually have any impact on climate change. I seek judgment from the court regarding the true value of our lifestyle.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on the True Value of Tiny Homes
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Societies have become more willing and able than ever to uncover the shady dealings that go all the way to the top.
docs.snippet: Societies have become more willing and able than ever to uncover the shady dealings that go all the way to the top.
docs.lead_paragraph: As the rogues’ gallery of fallen world leaders grows, you might be tempted to conclude that ours is the most corrupt era in history. Early last month, the former South Korean president Park Geun-hye was sentenced to 24 years in prison and fined $17 million for bribery, extortion and abuse of power. That same day, the former South African president Jacob Zuma, forced to resign in February by his own party, appeared in court to face charges over a $2.5 billion arms deal. The next day came an even bigger blow: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Brazil’s former president and current front-runner in polls for October’s presidential election, began serving a 12-year jail term on corruption charges — in a federal police building he himself inaugurated more than a decade ago.

headline.main: Corrupt Leaders Are Falling Around the World. Will It Boost Economies?

docs.abstract: Slow to melt in the mouth yet carrying a bold flavor, this dessert will pull you in with its sly power.
docs.snippet: Slow to melt in the mouth yet carrying a bold flavor, this dessert will pull you in with its sly power.
docs.lead_paragraph: Sometime during the first year that I was married, when I was teaching myself to cook, I enrolled in a cake-decorating class. A course on how not to turn steaks into hockey pucks might have been more useful at that stage of my life, but I was already in thrall to baking. I bought myself canvas pastry bags marked “Made in France” and outfitted them with a wardrobe of accessories. Each week, I would take my place in front of a ruled board, just as I had when I was learning cursive, and spend two hours squeezing Crisco (cheaper and more forgiving than frosting) into shapes that always fell short of botanical verisimilitude.

headline.main: A Simple Lemon Tart With Sensuous Surprises

docs.abstract: The actress and author on her time in Trump’s orbit and aging in Hollywood.
docs.snippet: The actress and author on her time in Trump’s orbit and aging in Hollywood.
docs.lead_paragraph: Your new book is part memoir, part self-help book. The through line seems to be that you are ambitious and love to multitask. How many different things are you doing at the moment? I’ve got a talk show coming out, produced by Dr. Phil. I’m back on “Empire.” I’m in “Sharknado 6.” The Vivica A. Fox Hair Collection has been picked up for another four years. I think that’s all. Oh, and I do Christmas movies too.

headline.main: Vivica A. Fox Wants Women in Hollywood to Last Past 35
headline.print_headline: Vivica A. Fox Wants Women In Hollywood To Last Past 35

docs.abstract: You don’t need to unplug entirely — just for an hour or so.
docs.snippet: You don’t need to unplug entirely — just for an hour or so.
docs.lead_paragraph: One of my best teenage memories starts with a natural disaster. In January 1998, my parents and I returned to our home in Montreal to find that a giant tree limb had ruptured our living room. What would soon be known as the Great Quebec Ice Storm had struck. It was the most catastrophic in modern Canadian history. Accumulations of freezing rain had cracked our maple tree nearly in half. It shattered our front window, glass fringing the tree limb like a body outline in a murder scene.

docs.abstract: Bore test holes near the shore. Don’t think or talk about politics.
docs.snippet: Bore test holes near the shore. Don’t think or talk about politics.
docs.lead_paragraph: “If you’re cold, you’ll think only of the cold,” says Dmitry Eliseev, Russia’s top ice fisherman and the winner of last year’s World Ice Fishing Championship. You must dress warmly, in layers, and take along a hot, nonalcoholic beverage in an insulated thermos. Before stepping out onto the ice, consider your safety. “Never go alone,” says Eliseev, 25, who has fallen through the ice five times since he took part in his first expedition, as a toddler. Know the ice. Ice is harder when it’s new, clear and blue; avoid ice that appears milky or is covered in snow. Using your auger (you’ll need one), drill a test hole near the shore. Don’t go out unless the ice is at least four inches thick.

docs.abstract: They’re not really about how the French live; they’re about us.
docs.snippet: They’re not really about how the French live; they’re about us.
docs.lead_paragraph: Several years ago, a website asked a bunch of contributors, including me, to write about our most embarrassing favorite books. When the piece went live, I scanned it eagerly at first, and then with dawning horror. Some writers listed fantasy novels, or flirtations with Ayn Rand. A few mentioned Kerouac. And then there was mine: “I did go through a period where I would covertly — but slavishly — read every book I could lay my hands on on how to be sexy/chic/mysterious/alluring like a French woman,” I wrote. It was, by far, the most embarrassing admission on the list.

headline.main: Letter of Recommendation: ‘Live Like a French Woman’ Books
